title: Council warns against attempt to build flats on FT’s riverside site
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Aug 1, 2015, 20:57 BST - UK Markets closed Council warns against attempt to build flats on FT’s riverside site By Christopher Williams | Telegraph – 8 minutes ago 17.59 +1.47 
The FT's iconic offices were not included in the sale of the newspaper to Japan's Nikkei 
A London council has warned Pearson (Xetra: 858266 - news ) and Nikkei, the new Japanese owner of the Financial Times, that the newspaper’s landmark building on the Thames must not be redeveloped for luxury flats. 
Pearson, the FTSE 100 education company, retained ownership of the building when it sold the FT for £844m last month . 
Nikkei has agreed a tenancy on commercial terms at the current building to begin with, but it is understood the company believes the FT requires more modern accommodation to continue its transition to digital publishing. A search for new central London premises is expected to begin almost immediately. 
Pearson’s decision not to sell the building with the newspaper sparked speculation that it intended to cash in by selling separately to a property developer. The site, overlooking Southwark Bridge, would be expected to fetch hundreds of millions of pounds. 
But Southwark Council said it would oppose any move to take advantage of the strong international demand for high-end residential property in central London. 
Labour councillor Mark Williams, responsible for regeneration, said: “There is huge demand for office space in Southwark, particularly in the north of the borough along the river. 
“The FT are in a substantial office building in an area where our policy is to retain and expand office space and employment. Any application for this site would need to retain or increase this space in addition to any other uses. 
“We did have initial discussions along these lines with the FT a few years ago, but nothing was formalised and no planning application was submitted.” 
Pearson explored moving the FT three years ago and was seeking a partner to develop flats. 
The newspaper moved to its current building in 1987 from Bracken House on Cannon Street, which Pearson sold to the Japanese bank Ohbayashi for £143m. The company declined to comment on its plans for the FT building. 
The issue of foreign investors snapping up London developments off-plan and often leaving them unoccupied has climbed the political agenda. David Cameron said last week the capital was “not a place to stash your dodgy cash”.
